posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: I was discussing the possibility of using an insta 360 cam to track April tags, and the first thing I think about is hooking it to an orange pi and running photon vision, because I assume it would is not much different than having a Microsoft cam. But I don’t know, do you guys think that this could be the future of vision because instead of needing 4 around the robot to see all of its surroundings you could just use one cam that sees all of its surroundings.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
Assuming we’re talking one of the actual 360 cameras and not their action cam, I suspect the processor overhead required to handle April Tag tracking even at the Insta360s minimum resolution (4K) would be far too high for an OrangePi to handle.

Aside from that, you’d also have to account for the heavy lens distortion of the fisheye cameras which might be possible to get around with calibration but still a challenge.

Incidentally, I’m not sure Insta360 cameras even support direct video output via USB/HDMI, I think it might only save to SD and allow data transfer, or maybe connect via WiFi (which would be illegal). EDIT: At least the X4 supports video over USB via “Webcam Mode”, though I wouldn’t be surprised if there’s a quality drop doing that (simply for USB-C bandwidth reasons).

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: I’m told the distortion caused by a fisheye lens can mess with tracking.  I’m not sure how much of that can be processed away. We had a 105 degree fisheye lens on our “final alignment” camera , and it worked fine for that purpose, although we kept the 70 degree lens for our “global pose” camera.

link_counts.title: Let’s Review REEFSCAPE’s Controls Software Strategy: How did you solve position and accuracy with software?

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: True I did not think about the processing power it would need, but I did a quick google and it looks like you can lower the resolution of a single can video down to 1080p and 30fps, But it looks like if you want to do a full 360 vid the lowest you can make it is 4k 30fps which kind of sucks

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Yeah, and generally FPS is more important than resolution when it comes to robot vision. A more powerful co-processor might be able to handle it (I have seen teams put entire laptops on their robots before for vision), but it seems like it would be a lot of work regardless.
posts.edit_reason: Automatically removed quote of whole previous post.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: I have never heard of putting laptops on robots but I heard the 254 put an android phone to do processing one year.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked: Laptops were kinda the OG way to do “good” vision processing way back in the day before Limelights and RasPis were a thing (that said, I saw one on a robot this year at MSC). The biggest limitation is the single-item cost limit, but you can technically get around it by purchasing the components individually (most laptop manufacturers will sell replacement mainboards, CPU and all, and you don’t technically need a screen or a lot of the other things). There isn’t really a lot of software support for that kind of solution though so it requires a lot of custom code and isn’t without issues (or so I hear).

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: Another option is using a jetson, which has CUDA cores you can leverage. Or pull a 6328 and use a Mac /j

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
cbale2000:

generally FPS is more important than resolution

Is this actually true? I’ve seen the argument that high fps @ low res is akin to getting worse data, faster. It doesn’t matter if you’re getting 100 fps if the estimates from those frames are off by multiple centimeters. Higher res will give better estimates, and you can use odometry to fill in the gaps

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked:
At the end of the day, it’s a tradeoff, and there’s some setting that will give you the best solution for your needs, it’s just a matter of finding what’s best for you. For us this season, we found that low res, high fps was best, but if we had different goals, we may have gone for different settings.

I think the reason high fps worked for us so well this year was because the time when we needed accurate vision the most just so happened to be the time we were closest to the AprilTags, which meant that even with low res, we were still getting measurements accurate to the 10th of a millimeter.

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
There’s probably a lower-limit to what resolution you can use, the main thing that lowering resolution does is affect the range of your cameras (since it won’t be clear enough of an image to see far away), but the actual “quality” of the tag, and subsequently, your pos, is more a factor of how much you “trust” it. The issue with lower framerates is that at the speed our robots run, latency kills, and getting position data that’s even a bit old can throw things off significantly, at least in our experience.

Don’t get me wrong though, if there was a solution that would reliably give us 1080p 90fps, I’d be happy to use it.

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: Idk if you’re using LimelightLib or PhotonVision, but Limelight’s software puts measurement latency on NetworkTables, so you can pull that, and then pass it into your pose estimator when using the addVisionMeasuremnt() method.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
I’m guessing they’re not using limelight, as to the best of my knowledge limelight doesn’t support alternative cameras.

If you’re using photonvision, there is a way to add a timestamp as well to the pose estimate. I don’t remember it off the top of my head, but it ought to be in the docs.

posts.name: Andrew Schreiber
posts.cooked:
Depends on what you’re trying to do really. “low res” can still have more than enough resolution for some tasks. With April tags the big thing it’s getting you is more detection range.

So if the tags are well placed you can forego range to get faster pose updates. Whether you need that or not depends on what you’re doing with it though. Keeping in mind the actual rate your robot code is running (which can be changed). You maybe don’t need 240hz update rates for example…

And of course, all this depends on what you’re using this for - if you’re using SolvePnP resolution matters a fair bit because noise in the image will result in worse output. But if you’re doing a particle filter based SLAM approach you can probably tolerate the lower quality data as it should end up averaging out  (bonus if you get loop closures)

As for the main topic - you can in theory. It’s technically fusing a pair of cameras with wide angle lenses. Idk if you can get that raw fused feed out. I’m not sure you can, but if you can, my biggest concerns would be a) latency, what’s the delay in that stitching process b) fisheye breaking the usual pinhole camera model a lot of systems use.

a) There’s not much you can do, it is what it is, you’ll have to work around it. b) This is just some extra code, there’s examples out there on how to do it… dunno if they work with what amounts to a spherical camera but I’d be shocked if there wasn’t research on it.

Personally, I’d stick with multiple cameras - it means you have more flexibility about placement and can avoid obstructing views with superstructure.
